segment.source: Log on as a batch job (Windows 10)
segment.target: Log on as a batch job (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Log on as a batch job security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Log on as a batch job security policy setting.

segment.source: Log on as a batch job
segment.target: Log on as a batch job

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Log on as a batch job security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Log on as a batch job security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which accounts can log on by using a batch-queue tool such as the Task Scheduler service.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which accounts can log on by using a batch-queue tool such as the Task Scheduler service.

segment.source: When you use the Add Scheduled Task Wizard to schedule a task to run under a particular user name and password, that user is automatically assigned the Log on as a batch job user right.
segment.target: When you use the Add Scheduled Task Wizard to schedule a task to run under a particular user name and password, that user is automatically assigned the Log on as a batch job user right.

segment.source: When the scheduled time arrives, the Task Scheduler service logs on the user as a batch job instead of as an interactive user, and the task runs in the user's security context.
segment.target: When the scheduled time arrives, the Task Scheduler service logs on the user as a batch job instead of as an interactive user, and the task runs in the user's security context.

segment.source: Use discretion when assigning this right to specific users for security reasons.
segment.target: Use discretion when assigning this right to specific users for security reasons.

segment.source: The default settings are sufficient in most cases.
segment.target: The default settings are sufficient in most cases.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, this setting is for Administrators, Backup Operators, and Performance Log Users on domain controllers and on stand-alone servers.
segment.target: By default, this setting is for Administrators, Backup Operators, and Performance Log Users on domain controllers and on stand-alone servers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Task Scheduler automatically grants this right when a user schedules a task.
segment.target: Task Scheduler automatically grants this right when a user schedules a task.

segment.source: To override this behavior use the Deny log on as a batch job User Rights Assignment setting.
segment.target: To override this behavior use the Deny log on as a batch job User Rights Assignment setting.

segment.source: Group Policy settings are applied in the following order, which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Group Policy settings are applied in the following order, which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: The Log on as a batch job user right presents a low-risk vulnerability.
segment.target: The Log on as a batch job user right presents a low-risk vulnerability.

segment.source: For most organizations, the default settings are sufficient.
segment.target: For most organizations, the default settings are sufficient.

segment.source: Members of the local Administrators group have this right by default.
segment.target: Members of the local Administrators group have this right by default.

segment.source: You should allow the computer to manage this user right automatically if you want to allow scheduled tasks to run for specific user accounts.
segment.target: You should allow the computer to manage this user right automatically if you want to allow scheduled tasks to run for specific user accounts.

segment.source: If you do not want to use the Task Scheduler in this manner, configure the Log on as a batch job user right for only the Local Service account.
segment.target: If you do not want to use the Task Scheduler in this manner, configure the Log on as a batch job user right for only the Local Service account.

segment.source: For IIS servers, you should configure this policy locally instead of through domain–based Group Policy settings so that you can ensure the local IUSRComputerName and IWAMComputerName accounts have this user right.
segment.target: For IIS servers, you should configure this policy locally instead of through domain–based Group Policy settings so that you can ensure the local IUSRComputerName and IWAMComputerName accounts have this user right.

segment.source: If you configure the Log on as a batch job setting by using domain-based Group Policy settings, the computer cannot assign the user right to accounts that are used for scheduled jobs in the Task Scheduler.
segment.target: If you configure the Log on as a batch job setting by using domain-based Group Policy settings, the computer cannot assign the user right to accounts that are used for scheduled jobs in the Task Scheduler.

segment.source: If you install optional components such as ASP.NET or IIS, you may need to assign this user right to additional accounts that are required by those components.
segment.target: If you install optional components such as ASP.NET or IIS, you may need to assign this user right to additional accounts that are required by those components.

segment.source: For example, IIS requires assignment of this user right to the IISWPG group and the IUSRComputerName, ASPNET, and IWAMComputerName accounts.
segment.target: For example, IIS requires assignment of this user right to the IISWPG group and the IUSRComputerName, ASPNET, and IWAMComputerName accounts.

segment.source: If this user right is not assigned to this group and these accounts, IIS cannot run some COM objects that are necessary for proper functionality.
segment.target: If this user right is not assigned to this group and these accounts, IIS cannot run some COM objects that are necessary for proper functionality.
